intro: Calamintha nepeta var. byzantina, commonly known as Byzantine catmint, is a perennial herb native to the Balkan Peninsula. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, characterized by its square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant features small, tubular blue or purple flowers that bloom in summer, attracting pollinators like bees and butterflies. Its foliage has a minty scent and is often used in herbal teas or as a culinary herb. It thrives in well-drained soil and full sun to partial shade.
